channel.title: Triton Framework Development
channel.description:
[IMG]http://i51.tinypic.com/2yydxzc.gif[/img]
[b]Introduction:[/b] [i]Trition Framework will consist of three developers (unless we accept more) and this server will be dealt with as much as possible, the framework will consist of simple things as the updates come along, but we hope that it becomes a successful development.[/i]
[b]Basic information:[/b] We're using Netty 3.2.4 final for an api
[b]Apply for a developers position:[/b] Name: Years of experience, previous releases/frameworks: What are you best at? Core/Content? Email:
If you cannot write basic java, don't waste our time.
[center][b][u]Developers[/u][/b] [center]- [b]`SJ_[/b] - [i]Core/Content developer[/i] - [b]Jmood128[/b] - [i]Core Developer[/center] - [b]Ix Soulcist xI[/b] - [i]Learning Core developer[/i] - [b]The Soul[/b] - [i]Content developer[/i] [/center]
[b][u]Update Log:[/u][/b] [code]
7/18/11 - Reading upon Netty networking 7/17/11 - Working on login 7/17/11 - Started working on a constants class that will handle all the basic things (so we can easily tweak codes). 7/15/11 - Started the player class (basic username/password strings to get started) 7/15/11 - Did a quick finish on the Server Engine, the server engine binds its port from a constant class 7/14/11 - Started on the ServerEngine class 7/14/11 - Started Triton Development [/code]
The current updates that we plan on having are simple things for a framework, and something for members to have a nice time on, or at least keep them occupied.
[center][b]Upcoming Updates[/b][/center] [center] - Login - Talking - Multiplayer support - Rendering - Basic Player Vs. Player - Dropping Items - Pickup - All the basic necessities [/center]
Please feel free to leave feedback and ask us how the development is coming along, obviously no media will be able to be shared until we at least have login finished.

item.title: Triton Framework Development
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Rix_, post:27, topic:404677”][quote author=Pure Slay link=topic=501693.msg3673027#msg3673027 date=1311056324]
104 * 104 is just the one that most people use because they don’t understand how maps work properly :L
[/quote]
Nope, everyone who has had a look at the RuneScape client knows that it is 104*104.[/quote]

Idiot. A pallete has a size range from a default of 104 x 104 -> 128 x 128 which are made of 8 x 8 tile chunks. As you can tell the quotient of both of those numbers is an odd number (n % 2 == 1), this is because the center of these pallets is known as the active chunk which is where your local player is put. Also to note, the ability to change the chunk size was not introduced until later builds as Emily was saying. This was to load more data as the player traveled around more and more and to accommodate bigger maps for the player to see.

Reference to these diagrams then learn to research your shit before you post.

Read full topic

item.title: Triton Framework Development
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

[quote="`SJ_, post:7, topic:404677"]Got it thanks.
@ The wanderer a map is 6464 a region however is 104104.

Thanks mate.[/quote]

Eh…

Regions can be:

104 * 104
116 * 116
108 * 108 - I believe, there is one around there

and other generated maps can be larger.

104 * 104 is just the one that most people use because they don’t understand how maps work properly :L

Also, what protocol are you aiming for?

Read full topic

item.title: Triton Framework Development
item.dc:creator: @meiscooldude meiscooldude
item.description:
@meiscooldude wrote:

You guys might consider following the 80/20 rule [80% design/20% code]. It seems like you guys are diving strait into programming.

I would seriously consider spending 80% of your time drawing up class diagrams, defining network protocol, and discussing the best way to go about this. After that 80% you should have an exact idea of how your framework will be set up [classes, their properties, and how the interact].

This usually produces code that is easily defined [and documented], no patch classes [Classes put in place to fix a design flaw, and after a while become a nearly impossible to replace piece of the system due to how many things depend on it], and is just very reliable and extendable.

Just my thoughts, good luck! [Granted, you may already be doing this]

Read full topic

What exactly is a gameframe?
[/quote]the look of it.
[/quote]Framework* sorry[/quote]

It’s everything thats in your servers core. Server Handling, etc. Practically what I vain I said.
In basic terms, its just a skeleton of a server.

Edit:
Instead of using a 500ms cycle rate I’m using a 600ms rate, for predefined reasons.
